factoid: The middle-aged retired naval officer was speaking in a room.
A small crowd was pressing around the middle-aged retired naval officer.
Pierre walked up to the circle that had formed around the speaker and listened.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was wearing a military uniform from Catherine’s time.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was sauntering among the crowd with a pleasant smile.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was acquainted with everyone in the crowd.
Count Ilyá Rostóv approached the group and listened to the speaker.
Count Ilyá Rostóv nodded approval with a kindly smile.
The middle-aged retired naval officer spoke very boldly.
The boldness of the middle-aged retired naval officer was evident from the listeners’ expressions.
Some of Pierre’s acquaintances, described as meekest and quietest, walked away disapprovingly after the speech.
Pierre pushed his way into the middle of the group.
Pierre listened to the middle-aged retired naval officer.
Pierre convinced himself that the middle-aged retired naval officer was a liberal.
Pierre believed that the middle-aged retired naval officer’s liberal views were quite different from his own.
The middle-aged retired naval officer spoke in a sonorous, musical, and aristocratic baritone voice.
The middle-aged retired naval officer swallowed his r’s pleasantly.
The middle-aged retired naval officer generally slurred his consonants.
The middle-aged retired naval officer’s voice was reminiscent of a man calling out to a servant: “Heah! Bring me my pipe!”
The middle-aged retired naval officer’s manner of speaking indicated dissipation and the exercise of authority.
The middle-aged retired naval officer asked: “What if the Smolénsk people have the right to raise militia for the Empire?”
The middle-aged retired naval officer asked: “Should we take Smolénsk as our patrimony?”
The middle-aged retired naval officer asked: “If the noble awareness of the province of Moscow thinks fit, it can show its loyalty to our sovereign the Empire in other ways?”
The middle-aged retired naval officer asked: “Have we forgotten the raising of the militia in the year ‘seven?”
The middle-aged retired naval officer said that the raising of the militia had only benefited the poor’s sons and thieves and other undesirable people.
Count Ilyá Rostóv smiled blandly at the middle-aged retired naval officer’s speech.
Count Ilyá Rostóv nodded approval at the middle-aged retired naval officer’s speech.
Count Ilyá Rostóv said: “And was our militia of any use to the Empire? Not at all! It only ruined our farming!”
Count Ilyá Rostóv said: “We have another conception: we will not have soldiers, we will have peasants, and we will get only devastation from them.”
Count Ilyá Rostóv said: “The nobility do not guard the lives; everyone will go and bring more wealth, and the sovereign only needs to say the word and we will all die for him!”
Count Ilyá Rostóv’s mouth watered with pleasure at the middle-aged retired naval officer’s speech.
Count Ilyá Rostóv nudged Pierre.
Pierre wanted to speak himself.
Pierre pushed forward feeling stirred.
Pierre was not yet sure what he would say.
A senator without a tooth in his head stood near the first speaker.
The senator had a shrewd but angry expression.
The senator interrupted Pierre.
The senator began speaking in low but distinct tones.
The senator said: “I imagine, sir, that we have been summoned here not to discuss whether it’s best for the empire at the present moment to adopt conscription or to call out the militia.”
The senator said: “We have been summoned to reply to the appeal with which our sovereign the Emperor has honored us.”
The senator said: “But to judge what is best—conscription or the militia—we can leave to the supreme authority.”
Pierre saw an outlet for his excitement when the senator spoke.
Pierre hardened his heart against the senator.
Pierre stepped forward and interrupted the senator.
Pierre began to speak eagerly.
Pierre occasionally lapsed into French or expressed himself in bookish Russian.
Pierre addressed the senator formally as “your excellency.”

Pierre said: “Though I don’t agree with the gentleman whom I have not the honor of knowing, I suppose that the nobility have been summoned not merely to express their sympathy and enthusiasm but also to consider the means by which we can assist our Fatherland!”
Pierre imagined that the Emperor himself would not be satisfied to find in us merely owners of serfs willing to devote them to his service.
Pierre implied that the nobility should be ready to make themselves for the Emperor’s service.
Pierre implied that the Emperor would not obtain any co‑counsel from us.
